Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Whether you love it or hate it, the listicle
– a blend of list and article – has quickly become a very popular content format. 22 brain facts, 29 Things Australians Say
(That Americans Don't), 17 things humanity ruined in 2015. Pets? Really?! Listicles are everywhere. So, why are they so popular? There are some ideas, based in science, that
explain why. Listicles are readable and easy to digest,
they’re kind of like the graphic novel of the internet. And they play a role in curating information. Researchers estimated that in 2008, people
consumed 60% more information than they did in 1960. Back then, the average American spent 7.4
hours a day, outside of work, watching, reading and listening to things; on the phone and
having conversations with other people. In 2008 that number was a 11.8 hours a day,
and today it’s closer to 13 hours. Because we consume so much stuff, we’re
pretty distracted. A curated list appeals to us. Part of this appeal is being able to skim
or quickly look at a listicle and process all of it’s content. The headlines help by telling us exactly what
we’re going to get: The 25 Most Huggable Pokémon. So, we’re satisfied. But this ease of processing information can
lead to some interesting effects. At the core of this is cognitive fluency–it’s
a measure of how easy it is to think about something. People like thinking about things that are
easier to think about, compared to things that are hard to think about. No surprises there. And generally, the more fluently you can process
an object, the more positive your response is to it. Let’s take a closer look. In one study, researchers showed participants
a statement, like “Osorno is in Chile” in colours that made it easy or difficult
to read. Moderately visible statements were judged
as true, and highly visible statements were judged as true significantly above what people
would choose by chance. The researchers concluded that fluently we
perceive things affects our judgments of truth. Another study found when participants looked
at images that were easier to process, they twitched their muscles into a little subconscious
smile. We can’t infer that reading listicles make
us smile, but consuming easier to process information just might. And easy-to-process information isn’t new
to the “internet age”, it’s had an important role throughout culture. “It certainly has” Okay here’s Mike, from Idea Channel. “Hey Vanessa! Yeah, it’s really easy to look our current,
list-laden moment and feel overwhelmed! Or like the internet, with all its distractions
and blinking animated GIFs and pictures of cute cats, has given rise to this particular
and particularly easy to digest format. The listicle FEELS like it’s VERY INTERNET. Mark O’Connell, for the New York Times,
writes that online browsing often seems like “a comic nightmare of futile enumeration. The point of counting is, in a way, to get
to the end of counting; but this is a counting that admits of no conclusion—a bottomless
inventory of everything and nothing.” Mark may be more right than he realizes. The listicle has been around for much, much
longer than the internet has, and may be on one of the central ways we’ve cataloged
and organized the world for a long time. It’s just that, with the internet, we realize
the true infinity of whats available for sorting and cataloging, and lists doing so. Like, 5 genius trashcan lifehacks or The 21
Most Important Raccoons Of 2015 or 159 Disney Quotes For When You Need An Instagram Caption
or 6 Video Games That Failed Before You Pressed Start or OK OK I’m gonna stop before this
becomes a listicle listicle. If you wanna hear more about the 29 different
ways listicles have been perhaps flawed–but definitely important and interesting–throughout
history, head on over to Idea Channel when you’re done here. Thanks, Vanessa!” Of course! But as much as we’ve liked lists throughout
history, it’s not a perfect format. Sure, some people will say “listicles are
ruining journalism”, but we don’t speak of the impact of the format as much as the
way it’s written. In my humble opinion, you don’t remember
listicles. You don’t learn things from them. I’ve tried to think about any list article
or video that I’ve read or watched in my entire life, and I can only remember two from
the past two years: 37 Signs You Grew Up In Australia In The ’90s and 20 Facts about
the Muppets. And I probably remember these because Agro’s
cartoon connection, zooper doopers and Kermit resonate with me on a deep emotional level. And this is the thing about listicles: they’re
just like a zooper dooper or a popsicle in that they’re appealing, you can start and
finish it in two minutes, and you’ll be somewhat satisfied. Some people even say that listicles activate
your brain's reward system, so you’ll finish wanting more. In his TED talk, psychology professor Peter
Dolittle says that your working memory is about the size of a pea. You need to use it to make sense of all the
information you encounter every day and it’s limited in its capacity, duration and focus. You tend to remember about 4 things for 10-20
seconds unless you do something with it–like apply that knowledge to something you already
know or talk to someone about it. Otherwise, any bite of information, is (in
a manner of speaking) in one ear and out the other. Don’t get me wrong, the listicle isn’t
a bad thing! It has a well-deserved place in the media
landscape as a piece of entertainment and our brains love that we can fluently process
them. But as pieces of education, I’m not convinced. And if you want to hear Mike’s voice again,
and even see his face, head over to Idea Channel for his take on humanity and the listicle. And, maybe to see 15 hedgehogs with things
that look like hedgehogs. See you next week.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In 2008, researchers estimated ___% of people consumed more information than they did in 1960.
Options: A. 45%, B. 25%, C. 60%, D. 52%
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: According to researchers, what was the estimated percentage increase in information consumption from 1960 to 2008? Options: A. 20%, B. 40%, C. 60%, D. 80% Correct Option: C
Question 2: How many hours a day did the average American spend consuming information in 1960? Options: A. 5.4 hours, B. 6.4 hours, C. 7.4 hours, D. 8.4 hours Correct Option: C
Question 3: Why are listicles appealing to readers, according to the transcript? Options: A. They provide in-depth analysis of complex topics, B. They are easy to digest and curate information, C. They are a new format unique to the internet age, D. They are only used for entertainment purposes Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the relationship between cognitive fluency and how people respond to information? Options: A. It makes information more difficult to process, B. It has no significant impact on how people respond to information, C. It leads to a more negative response, D. It leads to a more positive response Correct Option: D
Question 5: How can understanding cognitive fluency help content creators design more effective content? Options: A. Create more complex and confusing content, B. Design content that is easy to process and understand, C. Only create listicles for entertainment purposes, D. Avoid using listicles altogether Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is one way listicles can be used in content creation? Options: A. Only for entertainment purposes, B. To curate and organize large amounts of information, C. To create lengthy and detailed articles, D. To avoid using cognitive fluency Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the relationship between cognitive fluency and the appeal of listicles? Options: A. Cognitive fluency makes listicles less appealing, B. Cognitive fluency has no impact on the appeal of listicles, C. Cognitive fluency makes listicles more appealing, D. Listicles are only appealing due to their format Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is a potential drawback of listicles, according to the transcript? Options: A. They are too lengthy and detailed, B. They are too difficult to process, C. They lack depth and nuance, making them less memorable, D. They are only used for entertainment purposes Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the result of combining the concept of cognitive fluency with the format of listicles? Options: A. Listicles become less appealing, B. Listicles become more difficult to process, C. Listicles become more appealing and easier to understand, D. Listicles have no impact on cognitive fluency Correct Option: C
Question 10: How can integrating the idea of listicles as a tool for entertainment and education with the concept of cognitive fluency help content creators? Options: A. Create more complex and confusing content, B. Design more effective and engaging content, C. Only create listicles for entertainment purposes, D. Avoid using listicles altogether Correct Option: B
Question 11: What is a potential critique of listicles, according to the transcript? Options: A. They are too lengthy and detailed, B. They are too difficult to process, C. They lack depth and nuance, making them less memorable, D. They are only used for entertainment purposes Correct Option: C
Question 12: How can the effectiveness of listicles as a tool for education and retention be evaluated? Options: A. By measuring the amount of information consumed, B. By assessing the ease of processing information, C. By evaluating the retention of information over time, D. By only considering the entertainment value Correct Option: C
Question 13: According to the transcript, what is the average capacity of a person's working memory? Options: A. 2-3 things for 10-20 seconds, B. 4 things for 10-20 seconds, C. 6 things for 10-20 seconds, D. 8 things for 10-20 seconds Correct Option: B
Question 14: What is the name of the psychology professor mentioned in the transcript who discussed the limitations of working memory? Options: A. Peter Dolittle, B. Mark O'Connell, C. Mike from Idea Channel, D. Vanessa Correct Option: A
Question 15: According to the transcript, what is one way to make information more memorable? Options: A. By making it more complex and difficult to process, B. By applying the information to something you already know, C. By only using listicles for entertainment purposes, D. By avoiding the use of cognitive fluency Correct Option: B
Question 16: What is the name of the YouTube channel mentioned in the transcript that discusses the history and importance of listicles? Options: A. Idea Channel, B. Listicle Channel, C. Cognitive Fluency Channel, D. Education Channel Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 1: According to researchers, what was the estimated percentage increase in information consumption from 1960 to 2008? Options: A. 20%, B. 40%, C. 60%, D. 80% Correct Option: C**

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions ask about the estimated percentage increase in information consumption from 1960 to 2008, and both have the same correct answer (60%).

The index of the most similar generated MCQ is: **1**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Whether you love it or hate it, the listicle
– a blend of list and article – has quickly become a very popular content format. 22 brain facts, 29 Things Australians Say
(That Americans Don't), 17 things humanity ruined in 2015. Pets? Really?! Listicles are everywhere. So, why are they so popular? There are some ideas, based in science, that
explain why. Listicles are readable and easy to digest,
they’re kind of like the graphic novel of the internet. And they play a role in curating information. Researchers estimated that in 2008, people
consumed 60% more information than they did in 1960. Back then, the average American spent 7.4
hours a day, outside of work, watching, reading and listening to things; on the phone and
having conversations with other people. In 2008 that number was a 11.8 hours a day,
and today it’s closer to 13 hours. Because we consume so much stuff, we’re
pretty distracted. A curated list appeals to us. Part of this appeal is being able to skim
or quickly look at a listicle and process all of it’s content. The headlines help by telling us exactly what
we’re going to get: The 25 Most Huggable Pokémon. So, we’re satisfied. But this ease of processing information can
lead to some interesting effects. At the core of this is cognitive fluency–it’s
a measure of how easy it is to think about something. People like thinking about things that are
easier to think about, compared to things that are hard to think about. No surprises there. And generally, the more fluently you can process

perceive things affects our judgments of truth. Another study found when participants looked

smile. We can’t infer that reading listicles make
us smile, but consuming easier to process information just might. And easy-to-process information isn’t new
to the “internet age”, it’s had an important role throughout culture. “It certainly has” Okay here’s Mike, from Idea Channel. “Hey Vanessa! Yeah, it’s really easy to look our current,
list-laden moment and feel overwhelmed! Or like the internet, with all its distractions
and blinking animated GIFs and pictures of cute cats, has given rise to this particular
and particularly easy to digest format. The listicle FEELS like it’s VERY INTERNET. Mark O’Connell, for the New York Times,
writes that online browsing often seems like “a comic nightmare of futile enumeration. The point of counting is, in a way, to get
to the end of counting; but this is a counting that admits of no conclusion—a bottomless
inventory of everything and nothing.” Mark may be more right than he realizes. The listicle has been around for much, much
longer than the internet has, and may be on one of the central ways we’ve cataloged
and organized the world for a long time. It’s just that, with the internet, we realize
the true infinity of whats available for sorting and cataloging, and lists doing so. Like, 5 genius trashcan lifehacks or The 21
Most Important Raccoons Of 2015 or 159 Disney Quotes For When You Need An Instagram Caption
or 6 Video Games That Failed Before You Pressed Start or OK OK I’m gonna stop before this
becomes a listicle listicle. If you wanna hear more about the 29 different
ways listicles have been perhaps flawed–but definitely important and interesting–throughout
history, head on over to Idea Channel when you’re done here. Thanks, Vanessa!” Of course! But as much as we’ve liked lists throughout
history, it’s not a perfect format. Sure, some people will say “listicles are
ruining journalism”, but we don’t speak of the impact of the format as much as the
way it’s written. In my humble opinion, you don’t remember
listicles. You don’t learn things from them. I’ve tried to think about any list article
or video that I’ve read or watched in my entire life, and I can only remember two from
the past two years: 37 Signs You Grew Up In Australia In The ’90s and 20 Facts about
the Muppets. And I probably remember these because Agro’s
cartoon connection, zooper doopers and Kermit resonate with me on a deep emotional level. And this is the thing about listicles: they’re
just like a zooper dooper or a popsicle in that they’re appealing, you can start and
finish it in two minutes, and you’ll be somewhat satisfied. Some people even say that listicles activate
your brain's reward system, so you’ll finish wanting more. In his TED talk, psychology professor Peter
Dolittle says that your working memory is about the size of a pea. You need to use it to make sense of all the
information you encounter every day and it’s limited in its capacity, duration and focus. You tend to remember about 4 things for 10-20
seconds unless you do something with it–like apply that knowledge to something you already
know or talk to someone about it. Otherwise, any bite of information, is (in
a manner of speaking) in one ear and out the other. Don’t get me wrong, the listicle isn’t
a bad thing! It has a well-deserved place in the media
landscape as a piece of entertainment and our brains love that we can fluently process
them. But as pieces of education, I’m not convinced. And if you want to hear Mike’s voice again,
and even see his face, head over to Idea Channel for his take on humanity and the listicle. And, maybe to see 15 hedgehogs with things
that look like hedgehogs. See you next week.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Generally, the more fluently you can process an object, the more positive your response is to it.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: According to researchers, what was the estimated percentage increase in information consumption from 1960 to 2008? Options: A. 20%, B. 40%, C. 60%, D. 80% Correct Option: C

Listicles become more difficult to process, C. Listicles become more appealing and easier to understand, D. Listicles have no impact on cognitive fluency Correct Option: C

Create more complex and confusing content, B. Design more effective and engaging content, C. Only create listicles for entertainment purposes, D. Avoid using listicles altogether Correct Option: B

By assessing the ease of processing information, C. By evaluating the retention of information over time, D. By only considering the entertainment value Correct Option: C
Question 13: According to the transcript, what is the average capacity of a person's working memory? Options: A. 2-3 things for 10-20 seconds, B. 4 things for 10-20 seconds, C. 6 things for 10-20 seconds, D. 8 things for 10-20 seconds Correct Option: B

Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 4: What is the relationship between cognitive fluency and how people respond to information?**
Options: A. It makes information more difficult to process, B. It has no significant impact on how people respond to information, C. It leads to a more negative response, D. It leads to a more positive response
Correct Option: D

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions address the relationship between cognitive fluency and how people respond to information, and both indicate that cognitive fluency leads to a more positive response.

The index of the most similar generated MCQ is: **4**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Whether you love it or hate it, the listicle
– a blend of list and article – has quickly become a very popular content format. 22 brain facts, 29 Things Australians Say
(That Americans Don't), 17 things humanity ruined in 2015. Pets? Really?! Listicles are everywhere. So, why are they so popular? There are some ideas, based in science, that
explain why. Listicles are readable and easy to digest,
they’re kind of like the graphic novel of the internet. And they play a role in curating information. Researchers estimated that in 2008, people
consumed 60% more information than they did in 1960. Back then, the average American spent 7.4
hours a day, outside of work, watching, reading and listening to things; on the phone and
having conversations with other people. In 2008 that number was a 11.8 hours a day,
and today it’s closer to 13 hours. Because we consume so much stuff, we’re
pretty distracted. A curated list appeals to us. Part of this appeal is being able to skim
or quickly look at a listicle and process all of it’s content. The headlines help by telling us exactly what
we’re going to get: The 25 Most Huggable Pokémon. So, we’re satisfied. But this ease of processing information can
lead to some interesting effects. At the core of this is cognitive fluency–it’s
a measure of how easy it is to think about something. People like thinking about things that are
easier to think about, compared to things that are hard to think about. No surprises there. And generally, the more fluently you can process
an object, the more positive your response is to it. Let’s take a closer look. In one study, researchers showed participants
a statement, like “Osorno is in Chile” in colours that made it easy or difficult
to read. Moderately visible statements were judged
as true, and highly visible statements were judged as true significantly above what people
would choose by chance. The researchers concluded that fluently we
perceive things affects our judgments of truth. Another study found when participants looked
at images that were easier to process, they twitched their muscles into a little subconscious
smile. We can’t infer that reading listicles make
us smile, but consuming easier to process information just might. And easy-to-process information isn’t new
to the “internet age”, it’s had an important role throughout culture. “It certainly has” Okay here’s Mike, from Idea Channel. “Hey Vanessa! Yeah, it’s really easy to look our current,
list-laden moment and feel overwhelmed! Or like the internet, with all its distractions
and blinking animated GIFs and pictures of cute cats, has given rise to this particular
and particularly easy to digest format. The listicle FEELS like it’s VERY INTERNET. Mark O’Connell, for the New York Times,
writes that online browsing often seems like “a comic nightmare of futile enumeration. The point of counting is, in a way, to get
to the end of counting; but this is a counting that admits of no conclusion—a bottomless
inventory of everything and nothing.” Mark may be more right than he realizes. The listicle has been around for much, much
longer than the internet has, and may be on one of the central ways we’ve cataloged
and organized the world for a long time. It’s just that, with the internet, we realize
the true infinity of whats available for sorting and cataloging, and lists doing so. Like, 5 genius trashcan lifehacks or The 21
Most Important Raccoons Of 2015 or 159 Disney Quotes For When You Need An Instagram Caption
or 6 Video Games That Failed Before You Pressed Start or OK OK I’m gonna stop before this
becomes a listicle listicle. If you wanna hear more about the 29 different
ways listicles have been perhaps flawed–but definitely important and interesting–throughout
history, head on over to Idea Channel when you’re done here. Thanks, Vanessa!” Of course! But as much as we’ve liked lists throughout
history, it’s not a perfect format. Sure, some people will say “listicles are
ruining journalism”, but we don’t speak of the impact of the format as much as the
way it’s written. In my humble opinion, you don’t remember
listicles. You don’t learn things from them. I’ve tried to think about any list article
or video that I’ve read or watched in my entire life, and I can only remember two from
the past two years: 37 Signs You Grew Up In Australia In The ’90s and 20 Facts about
the Muppets. And I probably remember these because Agro’s
cartoon connection, zooper doopers and Kermit resonate with me on a deep emotional level. And this is the thing about listicles: they’re
just like a zooper dooper or a popsicle in that they’re appealing, you can start and
finish it in two minutes, and you’ll be somewhat satisfied. Some people even say that listicles activate
your brain's reward system, so you’ll finish wanting more. In his TED talk, psychology professor Peter
Dolittle says that your working memory is about the size of a pea. You need to use it to make sense of all the
information you encounter every day and it’s limited in its capacity, duration and focus. You tend to remember about 4 things for 10-20
seconds unless you do something with it–like apply that knowledge to something you already
know or talk to someone about it. Otherwise, any bite of information, is (in
a manner of speaking) in one ear and out the other. Don’t get me wrong, the listicle isn’t
a bad thing! It has a well-deserved place in the media
landscape as a piece of entertainment and our brains love that we can fluently process
them. But as pieces of education, I’m not convinced. And if you want to hear Mike’s voice again,
and even see his face, head over to Idea Channel for his take on humanity and the listicle. And, maybe to see 15 hedgehogs with things
that look like hedgehogs. See you next week.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: People usually remember __ things for 10 to 20 seconds.
Options: A. 1, B. 2, C. 4, D. 5
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: According to researchers, what was the estimated percentage increase in information consumption from 1960 to 2008? Options: A. 20%, B. 40%, C. 60%, D. 80% Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Grammatical tense 
is how languages talk about time without explicitly naming time periods by, instead, modifying verbs 
to specify when action occurs. So how many different tenses are there
in a language like English? At first, the answer seems obvious: there's past, present, and future. But thanks to something called
grammatical aspect, each of those time periods 
actually divides further. There are four kinds of aspect. In the continuous or progressive aspect, the actions are still happening 
at the time of reference. The perfect aspect describes actions
that are finished. The perfect progressive aspect 
is a combination, describing a completed part 
of a continuous action. And finally, there's the simple aspect, the basic form of the past, 
present, and future tense, where an action is not specified
as continuous or discrete. That's all a little hard to follow,
so let's see how it works in action. Let's say your friends tell you
they went on a secret naval mission to collect evidence 
of a mysterious sea creature. The tense sets the overall frame
of reference in the past, but within that, there are many options. Your friends might say a creature
attacked their boat, that's the past simple,
the most general aspect, which gives no further clarification. They were sleeping when it happened, a continuous process 
underway at that point. They might also tell you they had departed
from Nantucket to describe an action 
completed even earlier. That's an example of the past perfect. Or that they had been sailing 
for three weeks, something that was ongoing 
up until that point. In the present, they tell you that 
they still search for the creature today, their present simple activity. Perhaps they are preparing for their
next mission continuously as they speak. And they have built a special 
submarine for it, a completed achievement. Plus, if they have been researching
possible sightings of the creature, it's something they've been doing 
for a while and are still doing now making it present perfect progressive. So what does this next mission hold? You know it still hasn't happened
because they will depart next week, the future simple. Your friends will be searching 
for the elusive creature, an extended continuous undertaking. They tell you the submarine will have
reached uncharted depths a month from now. That's a confident prediction about what will be achieved 
by a specific point in the future, a point at which they 
will have been voyaging for three weeks in the future perfect progressive. The key insight to all these 
different tenses is that each sentence takes place
in a specific moment, whether it's past, present, or future. The point of aspects is that they tell you
as of that moment the status of the action. In total, they give us twelve 
possibilities in English. What about other languages? Some, like French, Swahili, and Russian
take a similar approach to English. Others describe 
and divide time differently. Some have fewer grammatical tenses,
like Japanese, which only distinguishes past 
from non-past, Buli and Tukang Basi, which only distinguish future 
from non-future, and Mandarin Chinese 
with no verb tenses at all, only aspect. On the other hand, languages like Yagwa
split past tense into multiple degrees, like whether something happened hours, 
weeks, or years ago. In others, tenses are intertwined
with moods that can convey urgency, necessity, or probability of events. This makes translation difficult
but not impossible. Speakers of most languages without certain
tenses can express the same ideas with auxiliary words, 
like would or did, or by specifying the time they mean. Are the variations 
from language to language just differents ways of describing
the same fundamental reality? Or do their diverse structures reflect
different ways of thinking about the world and even time itself? And if so, what other ways 
of conceiving time may be out there?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Perfect aspect in English is mostly used to describe actions that:
Options: A. Are still happening at the time of reference, B. Are completed before the time of reference, C. Start at the time of reference
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: How many kinds of aspect are there in language? Options: A. Two, B. Three, C. Four, D. Five Correct Option: C
Question 2: Which language has no verb tenses, only aspect? Options: A. Japanese, B. Mandarin Chinese, C. French, D. Russian Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the primary function of grammatical tense in language? Options: A. To describe the status of an action, B. To specify when an action occurs, C. To indicate the location of an action, D. To express the duration of an action Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the result of combining tense and aspect in language? Options: A. A more complex grammar system, B. A more precise expression of time, C. A more ambiguous expression of time, D. A more limited expression of time Correct Option: B
Question 5: In which field can understanding grammatical tense and aspect be particularly crucial? Options: A. Business, B. Medicine, C. Art, D. Both A and B Correct Option: D
Question 6: How can recognizing the differences in grammatical tense and aspect between languages facilitate? Options: A. More accurate translation and interpretation, B. More effective language teaching, C. More complex grammar systems, D. More limited expression of time Correct Option: A
Question 7: What does the relationship between grammatical tense and aspect reflect? Options: A. Different ways of thinking about time and reality, B. Different ways of describing the same fundamental reality, C. The complexity of language structures, D. The limitations of language in expressing time Correct Option: A
Question 8: How can the use of grammatical tense and aspect influence people's perception of time? Options: A. By creating a more precise understanding of time, B. By shaping their understanding of time and reality, C. By limiting their expression of time, D. By making time more ambiguous Correct Option: B
Question 9: What can the combination of grammatical tense and aspect create in language? Options: A. New ways of expressing time and action, B. More complex grammar systems, C. More limited expression of time, D. More ambiguous expression of time Correct Option: A
Question 10: What can the study of grammatical tense and aspect lead to? Options: A. A deeper understanding of how language influences thought and perception, B. A more complex understanding of language structures, C. A more limited understanding of time and reality, D. A more ambiguous understanding of language and culture Correct Option: A
Question 11: Why is understanding grammatical tense and aspect important in effective communication? Options: A. Because it helps to create a more complex grammar system, B. Because it facilitates more accurate translation and interpretation, C. Because it shapes our perception of time and reality, D. Because it is essential for conveying meaning and avoiding misunderstandings Correct Option: D
Question 12: What is the potential implication of the variations in grammatical tense and aspect across languages? Options: A. That language structures are universal and absolute, B. That language structures are relative and subjective, C. That language structures have no impact on our perception of time and reality, D. That language structures are irrelevant to human thought and perception Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

at the time of reference. The perfect aspect describes actions
that are finished. The perfect progressive aspect 
is a combination, describing a completed part 
of a continuous action. And finally, there's the simple aspect, the basic form of the past,

as continuous or discrete. That's all a little hard to follow,
so let's see how it works in action. Let's say your friends tell you

split past tense into multiple degrees, like whether something happened hours,

with moods that can convey urgency, necessity, or probability of events. This makes translation difficult

Question 9: What can the combination of grammatical tense and aspect create in language? Options: A. New ways of expressing time and action, B. More complex grammar systems, C. More limited expression of time, D. More ambiguous expression of time Correct Option: A
Question 10: What can the study of grammatical tense and aspect lead to? Options: A. A deeper understanding of how language influences thought and perception, B. A more complex understanding of language structures, C. A more limited understanding of time and reality, D. A more ambiguous understanding of language and culture Correct Option: A
Question 11: Why is understanding grammatical tense and aspect important in effective communication? Options: A. Because it helps to create a more complex grammar system, B. Because it facilitates more accurate translation and interpretation, C. Because it shapes our perception of time and reality, D. Because it is essential for conveying meaning and avoiding misunderstandings Correct Option: D
Question 12: What is the potential implication of the variations in grammatical tense and aspect across languages? Options: A. That language structures are universal and absolute, B. That language structures are relative and subjective, C. That language structures have no impact on our perception of time and reality, D. That language structures are irrelevant to human thought and perception Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Grammatical tense 
is how languages talk about time without explicitly naming time periods by, instead, modifying verbs 
to specify when action occurs. So how many different tenses are there
in a language like English? At first, the answer seems obvious: there's past, present, and future. But thanks to something called
grammatical aspect, each of those time periods 
actually divides further. There are four kinds of aspect. In the continuous or progressive aspect, the actions are still happening 
at the time of reference. The perfect aspect describes actions
that are finished. The perfect progressive aspect 
is a combination, describing a completed part 
of a continuous action. And finally, there's the simple aspect, the basic form of the past, 
present, and future tense, where an action is not specified
as continuous or discrete. That's all a little hard to follow,
so let's see how it works in action. Let's say your friends tell you
they went on a secret naval mission to collect evidence 
of a mysterious sea creature. The tense sets the overall frame
of reference in the past, but within that, there are many options. Your friends might say a creature
attacked their boat, that's the past simple,
the most general aspect, which gives no further clarification. They were sleeping when it happened, a continuous process 
underway at that point. They might also tell you they had departed
from Nantucket to describe an action 
completed even earlier. That's an example of the past perfect. Or that they had been sailing 
for three weeks, something that was ongoing 
up until that point. In the present, they tell you that 
they still search for the creature today, their present simple activity. Perhaps they are preparing for their
next mission continuously as they speak. And they have built a special 
submarine for it, a completed achievement. Plus, if they have been researching
possible sightings of the creature, it's something they've been doing 
for a while and are still doing now making it present perfect progressive. So what does this next mission hold? You know it still hasn't happened
because they will depart next week, the future simple. Your friends will be searching 
for the elusive creature, an extended continuous undertaking. They tell you the submarine will have
reached uncharted depths a month from now. That's a confident prediction about what will be achieved 
by a specific point in the future, a point at which they 
will have been voyaging for three weeks in the future perfect progressive. The key insight to all these 
different tenses is that each sentence takes place
in a specific moment, whether it's past, present, or future. The point of aspects is that they tell you
as of that moment the status of the action. In total, they give us twelve 
possibilities in English. What about other languages? Some, like French, Swahili, and Russian
take a similar approach to English. Others describe 
and divide time differently. Some have fewer grammatical tenses,
like Japanese, which only distinguishes past 
from non-past, Buli and Tukang Basi, which only distinguish future 
from non-future, and Mandarin Chinese 
with no verb tenses at all, only aspect. On the other hand, languages like Yagwa
split past tense into multiple degrees, like whether something happened hours, 
weeks, or years ago. In others, tenses are intertwined
with moods that can convey urgency, necessity, or probability of events. This makes translation difficult
but not impossible. Speakers of most languages without certain
tenses can express the same ideas with auxiliary words, 
like would or did, or by specifying the time they mean. Are the variations 
from language to language just differents ways of describing
the same fundamental reality? Or do their diverse structures reflect
different ways of thinking about the world and even time itself? And if so, what other ways 
of conceiving time may be out there?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In the sentence "They had been sailing for three weeks when the attack happened," the verb "to sail" has which tense-aspect form?
Options: A. Past Simple, B. Past Continuous (Progressive), C. Past Perfect, D. Past Perfect Continuous (Progressive)
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: How many kinds of aspect are there in language? Options: A. Two, B. Three, C. Four, D. Five Correct Option: C
Question 2: Which language has no verb tenses, only aspect? Options: A. Japanese, B. Mandarin Chinese, C. French, D. Russian Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the primary function of grammatical tense in language? Options: A. To describe the status of an action, B. To specify when an action occurs, C. To indicate the location of an action, D. To express the duration of an action Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the result of combining tense and aspect in language? Options: A. A more complex grammar system, B. A more precise expression of time, C. A more ambiguous expression of time, D. A more limited expression of time Correct Option: B
Question 5: In which field can understanding grammatical tense and aspect be particularly crucial? Options: A. Business, B. Medicine, C. Art, D. Both A and B Correct Option: D
Question 6: How can recognizing the differences in grammatical tense and aspect between languages facilitate? Options: A. More accurate translation and interpretation, B. More effective language teaching, C. More complex grammar systems, D. More limited expression of time Correct Option: A
Question 7: What does the relationship between grammatical tense and aspect reflect? Options: A. Different ways of thinking about time and reality, B. Different ways of describing the same fundamental reality, C. The complexity of language structures, D. The limitations of language in expressing time Correct Option: A
Question 8: How can the use of grammatical tense and aspect influence people's perception of time? Options: A. By creating a more precise understanding of time, B. By shaping their understanding of time and reality, C. By limiting their expression of time, D. By making time more ambiguous Correct Option: B
Question 9: What can the combination of grammatical tense and aspect create in language? Options: A. New ways of expressing time and action, B. More complex grammar systems, C. More limited expression of time, D. More ambiguous expression of time Correct Option: A
Question 10: What can the study of grammatical tense and aspect lead to? Options: A. A deeper understanding of how language influences thought and perception, B. A more complex understanding of language structures, C. A more limited understanding of time and reality, D. A more ambiguous understanding of language and culture Correct Option: A
Question 11: Why is understanding grammatical tense and aspect important in effective communication? Options: A. Because it helps to create a more complex grammar system, B. Because it facilitates more accurate translation and interpretation, C. Because it shapes our perception of time and reality, D. Because it is essential for conveying meaning and avoiding misunderstandings Correct Option: D
Question 12: What is the potential implication of the variations in grammatical tense and aspect across languages? Options: A. That language structures are universal and absolute, B. That language structures are relative and subjective, C. That language structures have no impact on our perception of time and reality, D. That language structures are irrelevant to human thought and perception Correct Option: B

**Transcript**:
[MUSIC] [MUSIC] Hey guys! I just learned about a dog named
Chaser. Chaser is a border collie who has a vocabulary of more than 1,000 words, that’s
like the same as a 4-year-old child. What makes Chaser even more special is that he
can even separate nouns from verbs. "take lips. Do it girl!"
"Good girl, good girl." "Paw lamb, paw lamb, Chaser"
"Good girl, good girl" "Nose ABC, nose ABC."
"Good girl, good girl!" This is Oliver. Oliver, you think you're smarter
than Chaser? What do you say? Yeah, let's go find out. Come on! Get your ball. Where's your ball? Get your bone. Where's your bone? Nope, that's your ball.
Where's your bone? Bone. Bone. Nope. Find your bone? Where's your bone?
Okay, so maybe Oliver's not that good at this particular test, but the fact that we even
try to communicate with dogs, and that they communicate back with us, means that the human-dog
relationship is truly something special. "Who's the best boy? (baby talk)" I… have been known to talk to dogs a little. (baby talk)
(baby talk) Or a lot. (baby talk) It’s hard to know if they’re responding
to the words, or just the emotion in my voice. Or the fact that I sound ridiculous. One recent
study suggests it’s both. Or all three. Researchers at the University of Sussex played
sounds out of speakers on both sides of a dog. When dogs heard commands stripped of
their emotional context, they turned their head to the right, suggesting they process
verbal meaning in their left hemisphere. And when they heard the emotional sounds in the
voice, but the words were jumbled, they turned to the left, suggesting they process emotional
sounds on the right. These experiments show that dogs can definitely
separate the meaning of words from the emotion attached. But how much information do they
take from each? When I ask my dogs “Do you want to go for
a walk?” they aren’t processing the real meaning of that sentence the way we do, like
“Hmm, lemme see, do I want to go for a walk right now? Get some exercise? Maybe I’m
just not feeling it today? I mean, I’m a dog, what does it even mean to WANT something?” As good as dogs are with words, in many of
our interactions there’s probably a good amount of Clever Hans at play. In the early
1900’s a horse named Hans was said to be able to solve simple math problems by tapping
his hoof to represent numbers. 2 + 3? Smart horse! It was later found, though, that
Hans couldn’t do math at all. He was just responding to tiny cues from his handlers,
maybe their facial expressions would tense as he got close to the right answer, or they
would exhale when he tapped the right number. Clever Hans demonstrates that while we might
think of language as something we experience mainly through our ears, we communicate meaning
using more than just sound frequencies. In his book "The Expression of the Emotions
in Man and Animals", Charles Darwin argued that the way that we outwardly express and
interpret emotions evolved from animals, and that our ability to recognize fear, happiness,
sadness, even across species, is universal, and innate. It’s something that we’re
born with. Today, scientists are still debating whether
Darwin was right, but recent research suggests that we do share one special bit of emotional
intuition with our canine companions. Dogs are the only non-primate animals that
seek out eye contact with humans. Their wolf ancestors, even tame ones, although they’re
close enough genetically to interbreed with dogs, won’t look us in the eye… which
is why you can never, ever trust a wolf. "How am I doing?" When reading emotions in other people we tend
to look disproportionately and unconsciously to the right side of their face.
Dogs share this so-called left-gaze bias, but only when looking at human faces, not
when they look at other dogs. It seems like they genuinely want to understand what we’re
telling them and what it means. We seem to understand them too, or at least
we think we do. Researchers in Hungary tested people’s ability to interpret the meaning
of recorded dog barks, and found that many people really can speak dog. What do you think this bark means?
[barking] [barking]
Okay, that dog's angry. That's pretty easy. What about this one?
[barking] [barking]
Okay, that dog wants to go for a walk. One more.
[strange noises] I have no idea what that means. If you think about it, this dog-human language
connection makes a lot of sense. We've co-evolved with these creatures for the past 10,000 years
or so. We've molded them from wolves into puppies with our hands and our brains, and
our voices. Even if we don't always understand each other,
well, they're always there to listen, and that's the real meaning of a best friend.
Isn't it buddy? [phone ringing] Wait a second. Sorry. Hello? Um, yeah, sure. It's for you. "Hello? This is Oliver."
"Hello. This is dog." "Oh, hey Luna!"
"Have you seen Vanessa? She's been out for hours! I miss her."
"Ruh roh!" Um, thanks Luna! If you want to find out more
about dog behavior head on over to BrainCraft and find out if they really miss us when we're
gone. Stay curious. Good boy. Oh, and special thanks to Oliver. [MUSIC]

Options: A. Wolves, B. Bears, C. Dogs, D. none of the above
Correct Option: C

Chaser can only process verbal meaning in her right hemisphere. Correct Option: B

Language involves both sound frequencies and non-verbal cues., D. Animals are incapable of understanding human language. Correct Option: C
Question 4: According to Darwin's theory, what is universal and innate across species? Options: A. Language and verbal communication, B. Emotional expression and interpretation, C. Problem-solving abilities, D. Memory and learning Correct Option: B

Humans and dogs only share differences in emotional expression., C. Humans and dogs share both similarities and differences in language processing and emotional expression., D. Humans and dogs do not share any similarities or differences in language processing and emotional expression. Correct Option: C

Question 7: What does the left-gaze bias in dogs suggest about human-dog communication and interaction? Options: A. Dogs are not interested in human emotions and intentions., B. Dogs are only interested in human verbal communication., C. Dogs genuinely want to understand human emotions and intentions., D. Dogs are indifferent to human emotions and intentions. Correct Option: C

Human-dog relationships are solely based on verbal communication., C. Human-dog relationships have evolved to involve both verbal and non-verbal communication., D. Human-dog relationships are irrelevant to emotional expression and interpretation. Correct Option: C

Critically evaluating the methods and conclusions of studies on dog behavior and cognition., C. Only considering verbal communication in human-dog interactions., D. Disregarding the importance of non-verbal cues in human-dog interactions. Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is essential for evaluating the implications of the Clever Hans phenomenon? Options: A. Dismissing the importance of non-verbal cues in human-dog interactions., B. Considering only verbal communication in human-dog interactions., C. Evaluating the implications for human-dog communication and relationships., D. Ignoring the phenomenon altogether. Correct Option: C

[MUSIC] [MUSIC] Hey guys! I just learned about a dog named
Chaser. Chaser is a border collie who has a vocabulary of more than 1,000 words, that’s
like the same as a 4-year-old child. What makes Chaser even more special is that he
can even separate nouns from verbs. "take lips. Do it girl!"
"Good girl, good girl." "Paw lamb, paw lamb, Chaser"
"Good girl, good girl" "Nose ABC, nose ABC."
"Good girl, good girl!" This is Oliver. Oliver, you think you're smarter
than Chaser? What do you say? Yeah, let's go find out. Come on! Get your ball. Where's your ball? Get your bone. Where's your bone? Nope, that's your ball.
Where's your bone? Bone. Bone. Nope. Find your bone? Where's your bone?
Okay, so maybe Oliver's not that good at this particular test, but the fact that we even
try to communicate with dogs, and that they communicate back with us, means that the human-dog
relationship is truly something special. "Who's the best boy? (baby talk)" I… have been known to talk to dogs a little. (baby talk)
(baby talk) Or a lot. (baby talk) It’s hard to know if they’re responding
to the words, or just the emotion in my voice. Or the fact that I sound ridiculous. One recent
study suggests it’s both. Or all three. Researchers at the University of Sussex played
sounds out of speakers on both sides of a dog. When dogs heard commands stripped of
their emotional context, they turned their head to the right, suggesting they process
verbal meaning in their left hemisphere. And when they heard the emotional sounds in the
voice, but the words were jumbled, they turned to the left, suggesting they process emotional
sounds on the right. These experiments show that dogs can definitely
separate the meaning of words from the emotion attached. But how much information do they
take from each? When I ask my dogs “Do you want to go for
a walk?” they aren’t processing the real meaning of that sentence the way we do, like
“Hmm, lemme see, do I want to go for a walk right now? Get some exercise? Maybe I’m
just not feeling it today? I mean, I’m a dog, what does it even mean to WANT something?” As good as dogs are with words, in many of
our interactions there’s probably a good amount of Clever Hans at play. In the early
1900’s a horse named Hans was said to be able to solve simple math problems by tapping
his hoof to represent numbers. 2 + 3? Smart horse! It was later found, though, that
Hans couldn’t do math at all. He was just responding to tiny cues from his handlers,
maybe their facial expressions would tense as he got close to the right answer, or they
would exhale when he tapped the right number. Clever Hans demonstrates that while we might
think of language as something we experience mainly through our ears, we communicate meaning
using more than just sound frequencies. In his book "The Expression of the Emotions
in Man and Animals", Charles Darwin argued that the way that we outwardly express and
interpret emotions evolved from animals, and that our ability to recognize fear, happiness,
sadness, even across species, is universal, and innate. It’s something that we’re
born with. Today, scientists are still debating whether
Darwin was right, but recent research suggests that we do share one special bit of emotional
intuition with our canine companions. Dogs are the only non-primate animals that
seek out eye contact with humans. Their wolf ancestors, even tame ones, although they’re
close enough genetically to interbreed with dogs, won’t look us in the eye… which
is why you can never, ever trust a wolf. "How am I doing?" When reading emotions in other people we tend
to look disproportionately and unconsciously to the right side of their face.
Dogs share this so-called left-gaze bias, but only when looking at human faces, not
when they look at other dogs. It seems like they genuinely want to understand what we’re
telling them and what it means. We seem to understand them too, or at least
we think we do. Researchers in Hungary tested people’s ability to interpret the meaning
of recorded dog barks, and found that many people really can speak dog. What do you think this bark means?
[barking] [barking]
Okay, that dog's angry. That's pretty easy. What about this one?
[barking] [barking]
Okay, that dog wants to go for a walk. One more.
[strange noises] I have no idea what that means. If you think about it, this dog-human language
connection makes a lot of sense. We've co-evolved with these creatures for the past 10,000 years
or so. We've molded them from wolves into puppies with our hands and our brains, and
our voices. Even if we don't always understand each other,
well, they're always there to listen, and that's the real meaning of a best friend.
Isn't it buddy? [phone ringing] Wait a second. Sorry. Hello? Um, yeah, sure. It's for you. "Hello? This is Oliver."
"Hello. This is dog." "Oh, hey Luna!"
"Have you seen Vanessa? She's been out for hours! I miss her."
"Ruh roh!" Um, thanks Luna! If you want to find out more
about dog behavior head on over to BrainCraft and find out if they really miss us when we're
gone. Stay curious. Good boy. Oh, and special thanks to Oliver. [MUSIC]

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What non-primate animal seeks out human eye contact?
Options: A. Wolves, B. Bears, C. Dogs, D. none of the above
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is unique about Chaser, a border collie, compared to other animals? Options: A. Chaser can only understand nouns., B. Chaser has a vocabulary of over 1,000 words, similar to a 4-year-old child., C. Chaser is the only dog that can separate nouns from verbs., D. Chaser can only process verbal meaning in her right hemisphere. Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which part of the brain do dogs use to process verbal meaning? Options: A. Right hemisphere, B. Left hemisphere, C. Both hemispheres equally, D. Neither hemisphere is specialized for verbal meaning Correct Option: B
Question 3: What does the Clever Hans phenomenon demonstrate about language and communication? Options: A. Language is only about sound frequencies., B. Language is only about non-verbal cues., C. Language involves both sound frequencies and non-verbal cues., D. Animals are incapable of understanding human language. Correct Option: C
Question 4: According to Darwin's theory, what is universal and innate across species? Options: A. Language and verbal communication, B. Emotional expression and interpretation, C. Problem-solving abilities, D. Memory and learning Correct Option: B
Question 5: What can be inferred about human-dog relationships based on the study of dog cognition and behavior? Options: A. Humans and dogs only share similarities in language processing., B. Humans and dogs only share differences in emotional expression., C. Humans and dogs share both similarities and differences in language processing and emotional expression., D. Humans and dogs do not share any similarities or differences in language processing and emotional expression. Correct Option: C
Question 6: What can recognizing the Clever Hans phenomenon help humans avoid in animal behavior? Options: A. Misinterpreting animal behavior due to subtle cues., B. Overestimating animal intelligence., C. Ignoring animal behavior altogether., D. Overreacting to animal behavior. Correct Option: A
Question 7: What does the left-gaze bias in dogs suggest about human-dog communication and interaction? Options: A. Dogs are not interested in human emotions and intentions., B. Dogs are only interested in human verbal communication., C. Dogs genuinely want to understand human emotions and intentions., D. Dogs are indifferent to human emotions and intentions. Correct Option: C
Question 8: What can be concluded about the evolution of human-dog relationships based on Darwin's theory and modern research? Options: A. Human-dog relationships have not evolved over time., B. Human-dog relationships are solely based on verbal communication., C. Human-dog relationships have evolved to involve both verbal and non-verbal communication., D. Human-dog relationships are irrelevant to emotional expression and interpretation. Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is necessary to advance our understanding of human-dog relationships? Options: A. Ignoring research findings on dog behavior and cognition., B. Critically evaluating the methods and conclusions of studies on dog behavior and cognition., C. Only considering verbal communication in human-dog interactions., D. Disregarding the importance of non-verbal cues in human-dog interactions. Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is essential for evaluating the implications of the Clever Hans phenomenon? Options: A. Dismissing the importance of non-verbal cues in human-dog interactions., B. Considering only verbal communication in human-dog interactions., C. Evaluating the implications for human-dog communication and relationships., D. Ignoring the phenomenon altogether. Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Every two seconds, someone somewhere 
in the world experiences a stroke. And one out of every six people will have 
one at some point in their lives. Strokes deprive brain cells of oxygen and are one of the most 
common causes of death and a leading cause 
of preventable disability. When someone experiences a stroke,
quick medical care is critical, and can often help avoid 
permanent brain damage. But what causes strokes 
in the first place? And what can doctors do to treat them? The brain makes up just 2% 
of your body’s mass but consumes more than 20%
of the oxygen in your blood. That oxygen is carried to the brain
through a system of arteries. Carotid arteries supply 
the front of the brain, and vertebral arteries supply the back. These are connected to each other, and divide into smaller 
and smaller vessels that get billions of neurons 
the oxygen they need. If the blood flow is interrupted, 
oxygen delivery stops and brain cells die. There are two ways this can happen. Hemorrhagic strokes are when a perforated
vessel allows blood to leak out. But the more common type 
is the ischemic stroke, when a clot blocks a vessel 
and brings blood flow to a halt. Where do these clots come from? On rare occasions,
a sudden change in heart rhythm prevents the upper chambers of the heart
from contracting normally. This slows down blood flow, allowing platelets, clotting factors, 
and fibrin to stick together. The clot can be carried up towards the arteries
and blood vessels supplying the brain until it gets to one 
it can’t squeeze through. This is called an embolism and it cuts off the oxygen supply 
to all the cells downstream. The brain doesn't have pain receptors,
so you can't feel the blockage itself. But oxygen deprivation 
slows brain function and can have sudden, noticeable effects. For example, if the affected area 
is responsible for speech, an individual’s words may be slurred. If the stroke affects a part of the brain 
that controls muscle movement, it can cause weakness, 
often just on one side of the body. When this happens, the body 
will immediately try to compensate by diverting blood flow 
to the affected area, but this isn’t a perfect solution. Eventually, the oxygen-deprived cells 
will start to die, leading to brain damage 
that may be severe or permanent. That’s why it’s important to get
medical care as fast as possible. The first line of treatment
is an intravenous medication called Tissue Plasminogen Activator, which can break up the blood clot and allow blood to flow again
in the compromised artery. If it’s delivered within a few hours, this medication greatly increases
the chance of surviving the stroke and avoiding permanent consequences. If Tissue Plasminogen Activator
cannot be given because the patient 
is on certain medications, has history of major bleeding, or the clot is particularly large, doctors can perform a procedure
called an endovascular thrombectomy. Using a fluorescent dye that illuminates 
the blood vessels under a strong x-ray, the physician inserts a long, 
thin, flexible tube called a catheter into an artery in the leg and maneuvers
it all the way to the blockage. A retriever is passed
through this catheter. It expands and anchors into the clot 
when it’s just past it. The catheter then pulls the clot out 
when it’s removed. These treatments need to be delivered
as soon as possible to preserve brain function, which means figuring out fast 
if someone is having a stroke. So how can you tell? Here are three quick things to try: 1. Ask the person to smile. A crooked mouth or facial drooping 
can indicate muscle weakness. 2. Ask them to raise their arms. If one drifts downward, that arm weakness
is also a sign of a stroke. 3. Ask them to repeat a
simple word or phrase. If their speech sounds
slurred or strange, it could mean that the language area 
of their brain is oxygen-deprived. This is sometimes called the FAST test,
and the T stands for time. If you see any of those signs, 
call emergency services right away. Lives may depend on it.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which arteries supply blood to the brain?
Options: A. Subclavian and axillary arteries, B. Vertebral and internal carotid arteries, C. Artery of Adamkiewicz, D. Ascending pharyngeal artery
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What percentage of the body's mass is comprised of the brain? Options: A. 5%, B. 2%, C. 10%, D. 15% Correct Option: B
Question 2: What type of stroke occurs when a blood clot blocks a vessel and interrupts blood flow to the brain? Options: A. Hemorrhagic, B. Ischemic, C. Vascular, D. Cerebral Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the effect of oxygen deprivation on brain cells during a stroke? Options: A. They become dormant, B. They regenerate, C. They die, potentially leading to permanent damage, D. They adapt to the lack of oxygen Correct Option: C
Question 4: Why is prompt medical care crucial in treating strokes? Options: A. To prevent infection, B. To reduce pain, C. To prevent permanent damage and improve outcomes, D. To reduce hospital stay Correct Option: C
Question 5: What should you do if you suspect someone is experiencing a stroke? Options: A. Call their doctor for an appointment, B. Try to drive them to the hospital, C. Call emergency services immediately, D. Give them medication Correct Option: C
Question 6: This question has been removed as the transcript does not provide information on how to prevent strokes. Options:  Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the relationship between the brain's oxygen supply and the occurrence of strokes? Options: A. The brain's oxygen supply has no impact on stroke occurrence, B. The brain's oxygen supply is directly related to stroke occurrence, C. The brain's oxygen supply is only related to hemorrhagic strokes, D. The brain's oxygen supply is only related to ischemic strokes Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the primary difference between hemorrhagic and ischemic strokes? Options: A. Hemorrhagic strokes are caused by clots, while ischemic strokes are caused by vessel damage, B. Hemorrhagic strokes are caused by vessel damage, while ischemic strokes are caused by clots, C. Hemorrhagic strokes are more common than ischemic strokes, D. Ischemic strokes are more common than hemorrhagic strokes Correct Option: B
Question 9: This question has been removed as it is not directly related to the provided transcript. Options:  Correct Option: None
Question 10: What can be achieved by combining knowledge of stroke causes, symptoms, and treatment options? Options: A. Improved outcomes for stroke patients, B. Reduced risk of stroke, C. Increased awareness of stroke symptoms, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 11: What is a potential limitation of the FAST test? Options: A. It is not widely known or used, B. It is not effective in identifying strokes, C. It may not detect all types of strokes, D. It is too complex for non-medical professionals to use Correct Option: C
Question 12: Why is prompt medical care important in preventing permanent damage and improving outcomes for stroke patients? Options: A. Because it allows for prompt treatment with TPA or endovascular thrombectomy, B. Because it reduces the risk of infection, C. Because it improves patient comfort, D. Because it reduces hospital stay Correct Option: A
Question 13: What is the name of the medication that can break up blood clots and restore blood flow to the brain? Options: A. Tissue Plasminogen Activator (TPA), B. Aspirin, C. Warfarin, D. Heparin Correct Option: A
Question 14: What is the purpose of an endovascular thrombectomy in treating strokes? Options: A. To remove a blood clot from a blocked vessel, B. To repair damaged blood vessels, C. To improve blood flow to the brain, D. To reduce swelling in the brain Correct Option: A
Question 15: What does the "T" stand for in the FAST test? Options: A. Time, B. Treatment, C. Test, D. Therapy Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is not explicitly present in the provided options. However, based on the content and intent of the ground truth MCQ, I can suggest a related question.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the arteries that supply blood to the brain. A related generated MCQ (Question 7) discusses the relationship between the brain's oxygen supply and the occurrence of strokes, mentioning the role of arteries in supplying oxygen to the brain. However, it does not specifically ask about the arteries that supply blood to the brain.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Every two seconds, someone somewhere 
in the world experiences a stroke. And one out of every six people will have 
one at some point in their lives. Strokes deprive brain cells of oxygen and are one of the most 
common causes of death and a leading cause 
of preventable disability. When someone experiences a stroke,
quick medical care is critical, and can often help avoid 
permanent brain damage. But what causes strokes 
in the first place? And what can doctors do to treat them? The brain makes up just 2% 
of your body’s mass but consumes more than 20%
of the oxygen in your blood. That oxygen is carried to the brain
through a system of arteries. Carotid arteries supply 
the front of the brain, and vertebral arteries supply the back. These are connected to each other, and divide into smaller 
and smaller vessels that get billions of neurons 
the oxygen they need. If the blood flow is interrupted, 
oxygen delivery stops and brain cells die. There are two ways this can happen. Hemorrhagic strokes are when a perforated
vessel allows blood to leak out. But the more common type 
is the ischemic stroke, when a clot blocks a vessel 
and brings blood flow to a halt. Where do these clots come from? On rare occasions,
a sudden change in heart rhythm prevents the upper chambers of the heart
from contracting normally. This slows down blood flow, allowing platelets, clotting factors, 
and fibrin to stick together. The clot can be carried up towards the arteries
and blood vessels supplying the brain until it gets to one 
it can’t squeeze through. This is called an embolism and it cuts off the oxygen supply 
to all the cells downstream. The brain doesn't have pain receptors,
so you can't feel the blockage itself. But oxygen deprivation 
slows brain function and can have sudden, noticeable effects. For example, if the affected area 
is responsible for speech, an individual’s words may be slurred. If the stroke affects a part of the brain 
that controls muscle movement, it can cause weakness, 
often just on one side of the body. When this happens, the body 
will immediately try to compensate by diverting blood flow 
to the affected area, but this isn’t a perfect solution. Eventually, the oxygen-deprived cells 
will start to die, leading to brain damage 
that may be severe or permanent. That’s why it’s important to get
medical care as fast as possible. The first line of treatment
is an intravenous medication called Tissue Plasminogen Activator, which can break up the blood clot and allow blood to flow again
in the compromised artery. If it’s delivered within a few hours, this medication greatly increases
the chance of surviving the stroke and avoiding permanent consequences. If Tissue Plasminogen Activator
cannot be given because the patient 
is on certain medications, has history of major bleeding, or the clot is particularly large, doctors can perform a procedure
called an endovascular thrombectomy. Using a fluorescent dye that illuminates 
the blood vessels under a strong x-ray, the physician inserts a long, 
thin, flexible tube called a catheter into an artery in the leg and maneuvers
it all the way to the blockage. A retriever is passed
through this catheter. It expands and anchors into the clot 
when it’s just past it. The catheter then pulls the clot out 
when it’s removed. These treatments need to be delivered
as soon as possible to preserve brain function, which means figuring out fast 
if someone is having a stroke. So how can you tell? Here are three quick things to try: 1. Ask the person to smile. A crooked mouth or facial drooping 
can indicate muscle weakness. 2. Ask them to raise their arms. If one drifts downward, that arm weakness
is also a sign of a stroke. 3. Ask them to repeat a
simple word or phrase. If their speech sounds
slurred or strange, it could mean that the language area 
of their brain is oxygen-deprived. This is sometimes called the FAST test,
and the T stands for time. If you see any of those signs, 
call emergency services right away. Lives may depend on it.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following statements is incorrect?
Options: A. Strokes can occur due to blood clots obstructing blood flow to the brain tissue, B. Patients experience pain during an ischemic stroke, C. Strokes only occur due to lack of blood flow to the brain, which happens because of the occlusion of an artery, D. FAST test can be conducted to quickly evaluate for a stroke
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What percentage of the body's mass is comprised of the brain? Options: A. 5%, B. 2%, C. 10%, D. 15% Correct Option: B
Question 2: What type of stroke occurs when a blood clot blocks a vessel and interrupts blood flow to the brain? Options: A. Hemorrhagic, B. Ischemic, C. Vascular, D. Cerebral Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the effect of oxygen deprivation on brain cells during a stroke? Options: A. They become dormant, B. They regenerate, C. They die, potentially leading to permanent damage, D. They adapt to the lack of oxygen Correct Option: C
Question 4: Why is prompt medical care crucial in treating strokes? Options: A. To prevent infection, B. To reduce pain, C. To prevent permanent damage and improve outcomes, D. To reduce hospital stay Correct Option: C
Question 5: What should you do if you suspect someone is experiencing a stroke? Options: A. Call their doctor for an appointment, B. Try to drive them to the hospital, C. Call emergency services immediately, D. Give them medication Correct Option: C

The brain's oxygen supply is directly related to stroke occurrence, C. The brain's oxygen supply is only related to hemorrhagic strokes, D. Ischemic strokes are more common than hemorrhagic strokes Correct Option: B

Because it allows for prompt treatment with TPA or endovascular thrombectomy, B. Because it reduces the risk of infection, C. Because it improves patient comfort, D. Because it reduces hospital stay Correct Option: A

Question 14: What is the purpose of an endovascular thrombectomy in treating strokes? Options: A. To remove a blood clot from a blocked vessel, B. To repair damaged blood vessels, C. To improve blood flow to the brain, D. To reduce swelling in the brain Correct Option: A
Question 15: What does the "T" stand for in the FAST test? Options: A. Time, B. Treatment, C. Test, D. Therapy Correct Option: A
